A 'contour line' (also 'isoline', 'isopleth', or 'isarithm') of a function of
two variables is a curve along which the function has a constant
value. Courant, Richard, Herbert Robbins, and Ian Stewart. What Is
Mathematics?: An Elementary Approach to Ideas and Methods. New York: Oxford
University Press, 1996. [http://books.google.com/books?id=_kYBqLc5QoQC&pg=PA344-
&vq=%22contour+line%22&source=gbs_search_r&cad=1_1&sig=ACfU3U2wWEkaeLRCYtZiHbjh-
_OH7eKgnJQ p. 344.] In cartography, a contour line (often just called a
"contour") joins points of equal elevation (height) above a given level, such as
mean sea level. [http://www.merriam-
webster.com/dictionary/contour%20line][http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/c-
ontour%20line contour line] A 'contour map' is a map illustrated with
contour lines, for example a topographic map, which thus shows valleys and
hills, and the steepness of slopes. [http://www.merriam-
webster.com/dictionary/contour%20map][http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/co-
ntour%20map contour map] The 'contour interval' of a contour map is the
difference in elevation between successive contour lines. Tracy, John C.
Plane Surveying; A Text-Book and Pocket Manual. New York: J. Wiley & Sons, 1907.
[http://books.google.com/books?id=lp0NAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA337&dq=%22contour+interval%-
22 p. 337.]

More generally, a contour line for a function of two variables is a curve
connecting points where the function has the same particular value. The gradient
of the function is always perpendicular to the contour lines. When the lines are
close together the magnitude of the gradient is large: the variation is steep. A
level set is a generalization of a contour line for functions of any number of
variables.

Contour lines are curved or straight lines on a map describing the
intersection of a real or hypothetical surface with one or more horizontal
planes. The configuration of these contours allows map readers to infer
relative gradient of a parameter and estimate that parameter at specific
places. Contour lines may be either traced on a visible three-dimensional
model of the surface, as when a photogrammetrist viewing a stereo-model plots
elevation contours, or interpolated from estimated surface elevations, as when
a computer program threads contours through a network of observation points of
area centroids. In the latter case, the method of interpolation affects the
reliability of individual isolines and their portrayal of slope, pits and
peaks. Davis, John C., 1986, Statistics and data analysis in geology,
Wiley ISBN 0-471-08079-9
